hadiths.english_translation: Narrated by Ibn Abbas: Concerning His saying (Exalted is He): 'And glorify the praise of your Lord before the sunrise and before the sunset' (Qur'an 20:130), he said: This refers to the obligatory prayers.

narrators.name: Surayj ibn al-Nu'man
narrators.full_name: Surayj ibn al-Nu'man ibn Marwan al-Jawhari al-Lu'lu'i
narrators.alternative_names: Abu al-Husain al-Baghdadi, Abu al-Husain al-Jawhari

narrators.name: Qays ibn Malik
narrators.full_name: Qays ibn Malik ibn Anas al-Mazini al-Ansari
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Surmah, Malik ibn Abi Qays al-Mazini

narrators.name: Asim ibn Rajaa
narrators.full_name: Asim ibn Rajaa ibn Haywah al-Ataki
narrators.alternative_names: Asim al-Ahwal, Abu Muhammad al-Ataki

narrators.name: Ibn Abbas
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim al-Hashimi al-Qurashi
narrators.alternative_names: Hibr al-Ummah, The Learned Man of the Ummah

chainIssues: Surayj ibn al-Nu'man is majhul (unknown) - no biographical data in reliable sources
Use of عَنْ (an) by Qays ibn Malik creates potential indirectness
Use of عَنْ (an) by Asim ibn Rajaa creates potential indirectness
Abu Ruzan is majhul al-hal with no clear identification
Discrepancy between chain names and text content - text mentions Asim ibn Bahdala and Abu Ruzan but chain order differs

potential_issues.issue: Surayj ibn al-Nu'man at beginning of chain is majhul (unknown narrator)
potential_issues.impact: This critically damages the chain's reliability. An unknown narrator at the start breaks the entire transmission link.

potential_issues.issue: Abu Ruzan (mentioned in text) is majhul al-hal - cannot be clearly identified
potential_issues.impact: Unknown reliability affects the chain between Asim ibn Rajaa and Ibn Abbas

potential_issues.issue: Multiple uses of عَنْ (an) transmission term instead of stronger حَدَّثَنَا
potential_issues.impact: Creates potential for omission or indirectness in the transmission chain

potential_issues.issue: This is a mawquf (stopped at companion) not marfu' (going to Prophet)
potential_issues.impact: The statement ends at Ibn Abbas (companion) not going to Prophet Muhammad ﷺ

chainIssues: This is a section header/chapter marker, not a complete hadith

potential_issues.issue: No chain of transmission - this is only a section header
potential_issues.impact: Cannot evaluate authenticity as no actual transmission is recorded

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok

hadiths.english_translation: Concerning His saying (Exalted is He): 'Ask the people of knowledge if you do not know' (Qur'an 16:43), he said: This refers to the people of the Torah and the Evangel and those who have knowledge.

chainIssues: No documented isnad is provided for this interpretation

potential_issues.issue: No chain of transmission provided - only interpretation without source
potential_issues.impact: Cannot determine from whom or through which chain this interpretation comes

hadiths.IISGrade: Disconnections But All Narrators Are Ok
Topics: Explanation of seeking knowledge from the learned

hadiths.english_translation: From Mujahid: Concerning the verse 'We did not create bodies for them' (Qur'an 21:8), he said: They have no soul. And concerning 'nor do they eat' (Qur'an 21:43), he said: they are prevented. And concerning 'We have sent down to you a Book in which there is mention of you' (Qur'an 21:10), he said: your honor; and 'It is surely an honor for you and for your people' (Qur'an 43:44), he said: honor for you and your people.

narrators.name: Umar ibn Rabi'ah
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Rabi'ah al-Iyadi, Umar ibn Rabi'ah

narrators.name: Mujahid
narrators.alternative_names: Abu al-Hajjaj al-Makki

chainIssues: Only one narrator (Umar ibn Rabi'ah) recorded in the chain
Mujahid is a famous tabi'i known for tafsir but is also classified as mudallis (Category 3)
No direct transmission indicator between Umar and Mujahid - text just shows عَنْ
This appears to be Mujahid's tafsir interpretation, not a hadith to the Prophet ﷺ

potential_issues.issue: Mujahid is classified as mudallis (Category 3) and uses عَنْ in transmission
potential_issues.impact: This requires very careful evaluation - Mujahid was generally reliable but as a Category 3 mudallis, his use of عَنْ creates potential for omitted or unclear connections. However, his tafsir interpretations are generally accepted.

potential_issues.issue: Incomplete chain - only records up to Mujahid
potential_issues.impact: This is a mawquf (opinion of Mujahid), not a marfu' hadith going to the Prophet ﷺ

potential_issues.issue: Umar ibn Rabi'ah's reliability and meeting with Mujahid not clearly documented
potential_issues.impact: Cannot verify that Umar actually heard directly from Mujahid

Topics: Mujahid's tafsir of Surah Al-Anbiya verses 8, 10, and 43
Interpretation of angels and their characteristics
Quranic exegesis on honor and spiritual beings

hadiths.english_translation: From a man, from Mujahid: Concerning the verse 'They glorify the night and the day, they do not cease' (Qur'an 21:20), he said: Their glorification is their breath. And concerning 'And whosoever of them says: I am a god besides Him' (Qur'an 21:29), he said: This refers to Iblis.

narrators.name: Umar ibn Rabi'ah
narrators.alternative_names: Abu Rabi'ah al-Iyadi

narrators.name: Mujahid
narrators.alternative_names: Abu al-Hajjaj al-Makki

chainIssues: Abu Salamah is majhul (unknown) - cannot be clearly identified
Text says 'عَنْ رَجُلٍ' (from a man - unnamed)
Mujahid is mudallis (Category 3) which creates reliability concerns
Multiple عَنْ terms indicate potential indirectness

potential_issues.issue: Abu Salamah is majhul (unknown) - critically affects chain reliability
potential_issues.impact: An unknown narrator in the chain breaks the transmission reliability

potential_issues.issue: Mujahid is mudallis (Category 3) using عَنْ transmission term
potential_issues.impact: Though Mujahid was generally reliable and his tafsir is accepted, as a mudallis his عَنْ transmissions require cautious evaluation

potential_issues.issue: This is mawquf (opinion of Mujahid), not a hadith to Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: Limited to Mujahid's tafsir interpretation authority

Topics: Mujahid's tafsir of Surah Al-Anbiya verses 20 and 29
Explanation of Iblis in the Quran

hadiths.english_translation: From Said ibn Masruq, from Ikrimah: Ibn Abbas was asked: Which came first, the night or the day? He recited: 'Have not those who disbelieve seen that the heavens and the earth were joined together as one unified mass, then We parted them' (Qur'an 21:30), then he said: Was there anything between them except darkness? That is so that they may know that the night came before the day.

narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Abd al-Samad ibn Ali

narrators.alternative_names: Abu Abdillah Ikrimah al-Barbari

narrators.name: Ibn Abbas
narrators.full_name: Abdullah ibn Abbas ibn Abd al-Muttalib ibn Hashim
narrators.alternative_names: Hibr al-Ummah, Abu al-Abbas

chainIssues: Multiple عَنْ terms create potential for indirectness
Abdullah ibn Abd al-Samad is classified as Saduq Yahim (prone to errors)
Said ibn Masruq and Ikrimah are both generally reliable but using عَنْ
Ikrimah is noted as mudallis but generally reliable when reporting from his master Ibn Abbas

potential_issues.issue: Abdullah ibn Abd al-Samad ibn Ali is Saduq Yahim (prone to errors)
potential_issues.impact: The chain contains a narrator with documented errors, which affects overall reliability

potential_issues.issue: Ikrimah (mawla of Ibn Abbas) is mudallis but reliable for Ibn Abbas narrations
potential_issues.impact: While generally reliable for Ibn Abbas, his use of عَنْ still requires careful evaluation

potential_issues.issue: Multiple عَنْ transmissions in the chain instead of stronger حَدَّثَنَا
potential_issues.impact: Creates cumulative potential for indirectness or omission in the chain

potential_issues.issue: This is mawquf - stopped at Ibn Abbas' answer, not marfu' to Prophet ﷺ
potential_issues.impact: Limited to Ibn Abbas' interpretation of the Quranic verse

Topics: Ibn Abbas' answer about night and day creation order
Dialogue and inquiry about Quranic interpretation
